column2: Are you confident in your chosen career path?
column3: What factors affect your career decision-making process?
column4: How_did you_choose_your_career_path?
column5: Have you sought advice from a career counselor or career advisor?
column6: Did you face pressure in choosing a career path?
column7: Do you think your current career choice aligns with your skills and strengths?
column8: Have you ever thought that the path you have chosen is not suitable for you? You could have done better if you had chosen another path.
column9: If you realize that your initially chosen career path is not suitable for you, are you confident in shifting to a different career path?
column10: Do you believe that choosing the wrong career path can lead to academic failure?
column11: Do you think schools/colleges should offer career counseling and guidance programs?
column12: In your opinion, what can educational institutions do to help students choose their career paths more effectively? (Open-ended)

column12: The Career Counseling Desk may not be the most effective method for guiding new students. Instead, I believe it would be more beneficial to employ multimedia support to present a comprehensive overview of various fields and their practical applications in the job market. Utilizing visual aids, we can demonstrate the professions associated with each study field, providing students with a clearer understanding of the career paths related to their chosen areas of study.

column4: Based on personal interests and passion
column12: Educational institutions can help students choose their career paths by providing more career exploration opportunities, offering career counseling services, incorporating career development into the curriculum, and making career information more accessible. They can also encourage students to take a variety of courses, provide opportunities for students to gain hands-on experience, connect students with mentors, and help students develop their soft skills

column12: There must be counseling sessions for students which can help in choosing their career path based on their interest and educational background. Mostly students don't know much about the sub-field of their programs, for example 85% of FSc (Pre-medical) students thinks there's just two ways to enter medical profession MBBS and D-pharm but infact there are a lot more. That's why i said there must be counseling and career choosing sessions for the students in their local institutes. That was just my point of view.

column12: I think it's up to us. If we have proper knowledge about the subject we are studying and how it can help in choosing a career then I think choosing the right career path is not difficult. Most of the students do not know about the subject in which they are taking admission. "And what is the career?" Everyone should know the answer  of this question, and it should be taught in school or college in every study period.

column12: In general, Schools should organise career counselling for matric Students so that they don't have to study those subjects whom are not necessary for his future journey. But In Pakistan we don't see anything like that even in universities Students are still doubtful about their career because they don't know still wheather they chose a right career or not. So if possible Societies of Universities should organise ka career counselling session where students van question about their respective careers to respective professionals. They should educate students on how to determine that you career is perfect for you and how it is not. Societies should also organise some sessions where professional can guide them about career opportunities, required skills and all about how to build strong academic background in order to achieve a successful career.
